abstract.p: Neil Makin letter is dismayed that Betsy Wade's April 9 Practical Traveler column focused on resorts for heterosexual adults; Sandals executive vice president John D Lynch replies$

block.p: To the Editor: I was dismayed and rather saddened to read your article ''Children, Neither Seen Nor Heard'' (Practical Traveler, April 9).

I am a coupled gay man who prefers to vacation away from young children. Why would the writer, Betsy Wade, spend a third of her space describing a well-known heterosexual playground such as Club Med? On top of this she writes two paragraphs about Sandals as being ''adult-only (in fact couples-only),'' an environment the proprietor Butch Stewart says is ''to allow people to focus on each other.'' Mr. Stewart's phraseology should read ''to allow heterosexual people to focus on each other.''
To the Editor: I was dismayed and rather saddened to read your article ''Children, Neither Seen Nor Heard'' (Practical Traveler, April 9).

I am a coupled gay man who prefers to vacation away from young children. Why would the writer, Betsy Wade, spend a third of her space describing a well-known heterosexual playground such as Club Med? On top of this she writes two paragraphs about Sandals as being ''adult-only (in fact couples-only),'' an environment the proprietor Butch Stewart says is ''to allow people to focus on each other.'' Mr. Stewart's phraseology should read ''to allow heterosexual people to focus on each other.''
Please, if you want to discuss quiet holidays for adults, be inclusive of all adults.

John D. Lynch, executive vice president for Sandals, replies: Everyone is welcome at our two Beaches Resorts in Negril, Jamaica, and Providenciales in the Turks and Caicos, regardless of marital/family status or sexual orientation.

As to the concept of Sandals, which has a heterosexual couples-only policy: Exclusionary policies (e.g., adults only, nudists only, etc.) are not unusual in the vacation business. At Sandals, we cater expressly to the niche market of honeymooners.
